makers.displaydate: 1887–1948; born Hannover, Germany; died Kendal, England
makers.displaymaker: Kurt Schwitters, 1887–1948; born Hannover, Germany; died Kendal, England

texts.textentryhtml: Schwitters, one of the most influential artists in the years after World War I, developed a singular practice that merged art and life, embraced disparate media, and utilized found objects and printed materials. In 1919 he named this body of work Merz—an invented word derived from the German Kommerz (commerce). He developed ingenious ways to unite collage and painting: in addition to adding pigment to his finished collages, Schwitters either selected colored papers or incorporated paper that he had previously painted over or employed for another purpose—as in this work, which also features train tickets.
